chapter.title: Installation and Setup
chapter.para: Support is provided at the following locations:

listitem.para: VE-Suite Forums - Users/developers can go here to access forums.
VE-Suite Bugzilla - VE-Suite's interface for bug tracking. Users and developers can view and submit bugs.

chapter.para: Installation of VE-Suite is fairly straightforward. Visit the Downloads section and locate your operating system.

Windows: Two installers, which guide you through the process of selecting various options, are provided for Windows. One installer, vesuite#.#.#_####.exe, contains the core VE-Suite binaries and .dll files. The dependencies installer, vesuite_deps#.#.#.exe, contains the binaries and .dll files of VE-Suite's dependencies, arranged into include, bin, lib, and share subdirectories.

UNIX: A tar.gz file of the current release of VE-Suite is provided. You can extract the VE-Suite.#.#.# directory from it. Instead of one central Dependencies folder, we provide the dependencies' RPM files. Be sure to install each dependency you need before you run VE-Suite.

section.title: Windows Installation
section.para: Installing VE-Suite and its dependencies follows the same procedure as other installations. You'll choose which components to install, their locations, their Start Menu folder, and whether to have a desktop icon.

Of particular note is which components to install. In large setups, certain computers will run the NameServer while others will handle the Conductor and Xplorer. If you only plan to run it on a single desktop, you'll want to install everything. Just leave all the checkboxes checked.
Go through the same process for VE-Suite's dependencies.

section.title: Setting the Runtime Environment
section.para: In previous versions, VE-Suite's runtime environment was set through text scripts. Now it uses VE-Launcher to set up the environment. Most of it is automated, but you need to be aware of two important variables it sets: VE-Suite's directory and VE-Suite's Dependencies directory.

VE-Launcher automatically determines VE-Suite's directory from the current working directory. Moving the Launcher out of VE-Suite's directory or starting it from a different directory will pass the wrong value to VE-Suite, causing errors.

The Dependencies directory is the only variable you need to set manually. The first time you start VE-Launcher, you will be asked to find the Dependencies directory. On Windows, it is the VE_Suite.#.#.#_Dependencies folder.
On Unix/Linux, multiple dependencies can be chosen. The only one you need to specifically select is VR-Juggler's directory.
If you're upgrading from an earlier version of VE-Suite, you can also reset the Dependencies directory by clicking the Change Dependencies Folder button in VE-Launcher.

section.title: Setting Menus, Icons, Filetypes on Linux
section.para: VE-Suite comes with a vesuiteConfig.sh script you can use to set up menus, icons, and filetypes for VE-Suite on Linux desktop systems. The script works for Gnome 2.8+ and KDE.
To run it, enter its directory and type in './vesuiteConfig.sh', followed by the arguments. The script accepts these arguments:

listitem.para: --gnome or --kde: Sets Gnome or KDE as the primary desktop. If neither argument is passed, Gnome is chosen as the default primary desktop.

--both: Installs on both Gnome and KDE. --gnome or --kde still need to be passed to set the primary desktop, because on most dual-desktop systems, one desktop inherits some preferences from the other.
--user or --global: Sets the installations to either user-only or all-users. If neither argument is passed, all-users is chosen if you have root access; other user-only is chosen.
--uninstall: Uninstalls the setup passed. Goes with any other passed arguments. Example: '--gnome --global --uninstall' would uninstall the setup created by passing '--gnome --global'.
